title: Distinguishing diet- and microbe-derived metabolites in the human gut - Microbiome
description: Background Human gut microbes metabolize food and host secretions, consuming and producing small molecules that are important to health and homeostasis. Here, we present an atlas of diet- and microbiome-derived metabolites in the human gut, constructed from a controlled feeding experiment of adults on omnivore and enteral nutrition diets. Results By comparing metabolite concentration before and after microbiome depletion with antibiotics and polyethylene glycol, we identified 2856 microbial products decreasing and 1057 microbial substrates increasing in concentration after depletion. We also identified 2496 diet-derived metabolites by comparing diet groups when the microbiome was depleted. Seven days after antibiotics, 98% of gut metabolites recovered to pre-antibiotic levels in the omnivore group. In plasma samples, only 93 microbiome-derived metabolites varied with gut microbiome depletion, indicating a limited impact on circulating metabolites. To demonstrate our metabolite atlas, we annotated metabolites associated with inflammatory bowel disease and identified the microbiome-derived metabolites altered in gut dysbiosis. Conclusions We identified metabolites associated with the metabolism of the human gut microbiome, mapping its overall metabolic potential. Furthermore, we measured the rate at which metabolites were recovered following gut microbiome disruption.
content:
Abstract

Background

Human gut microbes metabolize food and host secretions, consuming and producing small molecules that are important to health and homeostasis. Here, we present an atlas of diet- and microbiome-derived metabolites in the human gut, constructed from a controlled feeding experiment of adults on omnivore and enteral nutrition diets.

Results

By comparing metabolite concentration before and after microbiome depletion with antibiotics and polyethylene glycol, we identified 2856 microbial products decreasing and 1057 microbial substrates increasing in concentration after depletion. We also identified 2496 diet-derived metabolites by comparing diet groups when the microbiome was depleted. Seven days after antibiotics, 98% of gut metabolites recovered to pre-antibiotic levels in the omnivore group. In plasma samples, only 93 microbiome-derived metabolites varied with gut microbiome depletion, indicating a limited impact on circulating metabolites. To demonstrate our metabolite atlas, we annotated metabolites associated with inflammatory bowel disease and identified the microbiome-derived metabolites altered in gut dysbiosis.

Conclusions

We identified metabolites associated with the metabolism of the human gut microbiome, mapping its overall metabolic potential. Furthermore, we measured the rate at which metabolites were recovered following gut microbiome disruption.

Similar content being viewed by others

Introduction

Humans coexist with trillions of bacteria and other microbes in the gastrointestinal tract with the largest biomass being in the large intestine, constituting an ecosystem known as the gut microbiome. These microbes interact with digested food that reaches the lower gut and carry out a variety of biochemical transformations as they live together and compete for resources. The diverse set of small-molecule metabolites produced by the human gut microbiome includes molecules that cannot be produced by the host, such as secondary bile acids [1], indoles [2], and short-chain fatty acids [3].

Gut microbiome metabolites are critically important to human health and metabolism. The short-chain fatty acid butyrate is produced by gut bacterial fermentation of complex carbohydrates and is a main energy source for colonocytes [4, 5]. Gut microbes synthesize several B vitamins and vitamin K, which are in turn used by other bacteria and the host [6,7,8]. Bilirubin, a heme derivative, is secreted in bile and is further broken down into urobilin by gut bacteria. In the absence of this bacterial metabolism, bilirubin is recirculated and is thought to be the cause of neonatal jaundice [9, 10]. Bacteria also produce trimethylamine-N-oxide (TMAO) from l-carnitine ingested with red meat. TMAO subsequently passes to host circulation and accelerates atherosclerosis [11].

Previous studies have identified and characterized a range of gut microbial metabolites, but have not established a comprehensive atlas of diet- and microbe-derived metabolites in the human gut. The MicrobeMASST database provides metabolite profiles of individual gut microbes but not complex, interacting communities [12]. An observational study in humans identified microbe-derived metabolites by correlating bacterial abundances with metabolite profiles, but did not completely address the role of dietary metabolites [13]. Innovative isotope studies revealed nutrient preferences of bacteria and the molecular origins of many bacterial metabolites [14]. Other metagenomics studies identified genes that allow bacteria to use alternative electron acceptors to derive energy from dietary and host metabolites [15]. Another metabolomics study compared germ-free and conventionally raised mice and identified hundreds of microbe-derived metabolites in the gut, plasma, and cerebrospinal fluid [16]. A powerful method to identify bacterial metabolites in colonized hosts is to reduce the biomass of bacteria in the gut, a strategy that is often used in murine model systems via the use of oral antibiotics [14]. In our study, we sought to derive the gut microbial metabolite atlas in humans, identify diet-derived metabolites, and demonstrate the relevance of this atlas to future research.

Here, we present a new analysis to deconvolute microbe- and diet-derived small-molecule metabolites in the gut. We re-analyzed the metabolomics data obtained from a controlled feeding experiment of omnivore subjects randomized to receive either a defined omnivore diet or an exclusive enteral nutrition (EEN) diet, previously published as the Food and Resulting Microbial Metabolites (FARMM) study [17]. As part of the study, the subjects were given antibiotics and polyethylene glycol (PEG) to purge their intestinal tract, thereby reducing bacterial load by approximately five logs. In the original paper, where we focused on the recovery of the gut microbiome from a gut purge under three different diets, we reported increases in bacterial amino acid derivatives during the recovery phase. This inspired us to systematically compare metabolomic profiles before and after the gut purge for both diets in this paper, to identify microbe- and diet-derived metabolites in stool and plasma of humans.

Results

Distinguishing diet- and microbiome-derived metabolites in the human gut

As described in Tanes et al. [17], we carried out a 15-day inpatient study where 20 omnivore participants were randomized to receive either a defined omnivorous diet (omnivore group) or exclusive enteral nutrition (EEN group) for the duration of the study (Fig. 1A). The EEN diet, which lacks fiber provides a contrast to the omnivore diet prevalent in industrialized societies. On days 6–8 of the study, all subjects were given a combination of two non-absorbable oral antibiotics, vancomycin and neomycin, to deplete the gut microbiome. On day 7 of the study, all subjects were given polyethylene glycol to purge the lower gut of fecal material.

We re-analyzed untargeted metabolomics data from this study to identify diet- and microbiome-derived metabolites in fecal and plasma samples by assembling a set of core comparisons from days 5 (pre-abx) and 9 (post-abx) of the study (Fig. 1B). Fecal and plasma samples collected pre-abx reflect an intact microbiome, and those collected post-abx reflect a depleted microbiome. When the microbiome is depleted, we expect metabolites produced by an intact microbiome to decrease in concentration. Hereafter, we refer to metabolites with this association as microbial products. Likewise, we expect metabolites consumed by an intact microbiome to increase in concentration. Similarly, we use the term microbial substrates to refer to metabolites that increase when the microbiome is depleted. There are some caveats in the interpretation of the results. Since the purge intervention is a combination of decreasing microbial load and decreasing transit time, some of the diet-associated metabolites and host secretions may be annotated as microbial substrates. Furthermore, both groups consumed a clear liquid diet on day 7 ad libitum, which was different than the defined menus. To minimize the effect of this on the study results, participants resumed their assigned diet for a full day before we collected the post-purge fecal samples. Any residual effects of the clear liquid diet would be expected to be non-differential between the two diet groups, thereby biasing toward the null for analyses of diet-derived metabolites using samples from day 9. For identification of microbial-derived or diet-derived metabolites using within-subject comparisons, the direction of bias cannot be confidently predicted, but is expected to be small based on having resumed their assigned diet for a full day prior to sample collection. We carried out these comparisons in the context of both omnivore and EEN diets. Subjects on vegan diets from the original study were not included in this analysis since they did not have defined diets and continued to follow their choice of vegan diet as outpatients. To identify diet-derived metabolites without interference from microbial metabolism, we compared metabolite concentrations between both diets when the microbiome was depleted. Comparing the metabolites between diet groups with intact microbiome allowed us to evaluate diet-derived metabolites under active microbial metabolism.

Our comparisons across time points and diet groups revealed thousands of diet- and microbiome-derived metabolites in the fecal samples (Fig. 1C; Additional file 1: Fig. S1). In the omnivore group, we detected 1057 metabolites that increased post-abx, representing microbial substrates, and 2856 metabolites that decreased, representing microbial products. Similarly, in the EEN group, we identified 1059 microbial substrates and 2278 products. In the depleted microbiome, we detected 2496 metabolites that were higher in the omnivore group (omnivore-derived) and 835 metabolites that were higher in the EEN group (EEN-derived). In the context of an intact microbiome, we detected only 162 omnivore-derived and 158 EEN-derived metabolites, reflecting the microbiome’s considerable flexibility in metabolizing diet-derived substrates.

Most metabolites identified in the comparisons were either unnamed or potentially fragments, isotopes, or adducts of other known metabolites (Fig. 1D), underscoring the vast unexplored metabolic potential of the gut microbiome. Microbial products and substrates identified in the omnivore and EEN groups were overlapping, with 38% of the omnivore products also identified in the EEN group. This high overlap suggests either that the gut microbiome can produce a core set of metabolites from diverse substrate pools or that the majority of the microbial metabolites are produced from a number of essential metabolites common to both diets. By contrast, only 7% of the diet-derived molecules identified post-abx were also identified pre-abx.

A secondary bile acid, lithocholic acid, and a short-chain fatty acid, butyric acid levels decreased the most among gut microbe-derived metabolites (Fig. 1E). Both have been extensively studied as microbial products in the gut [1, 3, 14]. Among microbial substrates, we identified hippuric acid as having the greatest fold change between intact and depleted microbiome (Fig. 1E). Otherwise, the list of metabolites consumed by the gut microbiome was dominated by a variety of acylcarnitines.

Among named diet-derived metabolites, shikimic and nicotinic acids (a B3 vitamin) had undetectable levels in the EEN group post-abx (Fig. 1F). Other plant-derived metabolites, namely masilinic and quinic acids, exhibited lower but detectable concentrations. Conversely, the concentration of caprylic acid and a number of triacylglycerides were increased in the EEN group when the microbiome was depleted, indicating the composition of a milk fat-based diet.

In summary, we constructed a comprehensive atlas of 8712 microbe- and diet-derived metabolites in human subjects (Additional file 2: Table S1).

Diet- and microbiome-derived fecal metabolites with known metabolic pathways

We annotated the metabolites with functional categories to identify trends with microbial- and diet-derived metabolites. The microbiome-derived pathways include bile acids, heme, benzoate, tryptophan, and phenylalanine derivatives. Histidine derivatives were omnivore-derived with some of the highest fold changes, whereas EEN-derived molecules were enriched with triacylglycerides. We identified acylcarnitines as both microbial- and diet-derived.

Primary conjugated bile acids are produced by the liver and secreted into the gut lumen to aid with digestion. The bile acids that are not reabsorbed back into the blood circulation interact with the gut microbiome to be deconjugated and then dehydroxylated. In the depleted microbiome, we identified increased levels of all major primary conjugated bile acids and conjugated deoxycholic acid as well as decreased levels of two major deconjugated bile acids: lithocholic and deoxycholic acids (Fig. 2A).

Heme, the oxygen-binding molecule in hemoglobin, is broken down to biliverdin and bilirubin by the host. After being conjugated in the liver, bilirubin is secreted into the gut lumen [10]. In our dataset, the levels of unconjugated host metabolites, biliverdin and bilirubin, were not altered based on microbiome content or diet (Fig. 2B). Mesobilirubinogen and l-urobilin, downstream microbial products of bilirubin, were higher in the intact microbiome than the depleted microbiome.

We identified hippuric acid as the microbial substrate with the largest effect size (Fig. 1E). Its downstream products, gentisic acid and pyrocatechol, were higher in the intact microbiome only in the omnivore group (4th and 7th largest effect sizes, respectively, Fig. 1E), suggesting diet dependence. The intermediate product benzoic acid has not been identified as a microbial metabolite (Fig. 2C).

Clostridium species containing the fld gene cluster reduce aromatic amino acids tryptophan, phenylalanine, and tyrosine to various metabolites [2]. In our dataset, we identified the essential aromatic amino acids, phenylalanine and tryptophan, as microbial substrates and their reduced derivatives phenyllactic, indoleacetic, and indole-3-proprionic acids as bacterial products (Fig. 2D). Phenylacetic acid is a product of the oxidative pathway that degrades phenylalanine [18]. We identified its conjugate, phenylacetylglutamine, as a microbial substrate. In plants, phenylalanine gets converted into cinnamic acid [19]. We identified its conjugate cinnamolyglycine as a microbial substrate and its hydroxylated form, hydrocinnamic acid, as a microbial product.

Amino acids are ingested as part of the diet. In our dataset, we were able to identify histidine and 12 metabolites derived from it (Fig. 2E). Histidine was equally provided by both diets; however, anserine and N-acetylhistamine were almost exclusively provided by the omnivore diet. Histamine, 1-methylhistidine, and l-histidinol were provided more from the omnivore diet. Imidazoleacetic acid was the only metabolite with higher levels in the EEN diet.

Glutamic acid can be converted into ornithine by the gut microbiome, which then feeds into the urea cycle. In our dataset, we identified glutamic and aspartic acids as substrates and N-acetylglutamic acid, N-acetylornithine, and citrulline as products (Additional file 1: Fig. S2).

The EEN group was fed a milk-based formula with corn syrup, casein, sugar, milk fat, and medium-chain triglycerides listed as top ingredients. When we compared the metabolomic profiles of both diets in the depleted microbiome, we identified various triacylglycerides with acyl lengths of 38 to 49 as mostly originating from EEN (Fig. 2F). The triacylglycerides with carbon chains longer than 49 were common between both omnivore and EEN diets.

Acylcarnitines are composed of an acyl chain conjugated with a carnitine molecule. We detected 52 acylcarnitines with various acyl chain lengths in the fecal samples (Fig. 2G). Six acylcarnitines with shorter acyl chain lengths were provided by the omnivore diet and consumed by the microbiome. Twenty-eight of the longer-chain acylcarnitines were provided from both omnivore and EEN diets and consumed by gut bacteria. One of the longest acylcarnitines, CAR C20:4, was produced by the gut microbiome.

Reversibility of gut microbial metabolite levels after microbiome depletion

To characterize the reversibility of microbe-derived metabolites after antibiotic intervention, we analyzed fecal metabolomics results at days 12 (4 days post-antibiotics, post + 4) and 15 (7 days post-antibiotics, post + 7) of the study. We first investigated the omnivore group, because based on our previous findings, the gut microbiome did not recover as rapidly in the EEN diet group [17]. By post + 4 time point, 91% of microbial products increased and 82% of microbial substrates decreased to pre-abx levels (Fig. 3A). Overall, 98% of microbial metabolites returned to pre-abx levels by the end of the study.

The gut microbiome uses amino acids as a source of carbon through Stickland fermentation. We identified 11 amino acids as microbial substrates. Of these, cystine increased by the greatest amount post-abx. The essential amino acids histidine, phenylalanine, threonine, and tryptophan were also identified as substrates. All substrate amino acid concentrations returned to pre-antibiotic levels by post + 4 (Fig. 3B). Valine, another essential amino acid that was not identified as a substrate, increased in concentration temporarily post + 4.

The B vitamins thiamine (B1), riboflavin (B2), nicotinic acid (B3), panthothenic acid (B5), pyridoxal (B6), and pyridoxamine (B6) decreased with microbiome depletion. All but thiamine recovered to pre-abx levels by post + 4 (Fig. 3C). Biotin showed a trend of delayed decrease. Folic acid was the only B vitamin with an increasing trend post-abx.

While the concentration of both primary and secondary conjugated bile acids decreased to pre-antibiotics levels by post + 4 in most subjects, deoxycholic acid recovered later by post + 7, and lithocholic acid had not recovered to pre-abx levels by the end of the study (Fig. 3D). Furthermore, levels of tyrosocholic and leucocholic acid, recently discovered alternate conjugates of cholic acid [20], were identified as microbial products and their levels recovered by post + 4 (Fig. 3E).

Overall, acylcarnitine levels were slow to recover after cessation of antibiotics (Fig. 3F). Of the 34 carnitines identified as microbial substrates, 30 did not recover by post + 4 and 14 had not yet recovered by post + 7. The only acylcarnitine identified as a microbial product, CAR C20:4, remained elevated at post + 4, but decreased to pre-antibiotics levels by post + 7.

The microbiome of subjects on EEN was slower to recover compared to the omnivore group after antibiotics and gut purge [17]. This was also reflected in the recovery of metabolites (Additional file 1: Fig. S3A). By post + 4, only 75% of the microbial products and 68% of microbial substrates had recovered. By the end of the study, 4.5% of microbial products and 1.2% of microbial substrates were yet to recover. By post + 7, levels of microbial substrates such as hippuric acid and cinnamoylglycine were still higher than pre-abx levels, while they had recovered by post + 4 in the omnivore group (Additional file 1: Fig. S3B).

Response of plasma metabolites to diet and microbiome depletion

Next, using the same core comparisons we described in Fig. 1B, we identified microbiome- and diet-derived metabolites in plasma. The number of metabolites we identified in plasma was far less than in feces (Fig. 4A). In plasma, there were 93 microbiome-derived metabolites in omnivore and 86 in EEN contexts compared to 3913 and 3337 metabolites, respectively, in feces. The number of diet-derived metabolites in plasma was 9% of what we identified in feces. Only 10 plasma metabolites increased and 83 decreased with microbiome depletion (Fig. 4B, Additional file 1: Fig. S4). Most of these microbial products were common between the omnivore and EEN diet groups (Fig. 4C).

Among the microbe-derived metabolites that circulate systemically, 3-indolepropionic acid had the largest fold change decrease (Fig. 4D) along with several bile acids, including chenodeoxycholic, deoxycholic, and glycolithocholic acids. The phenylalanine derivative cinnamoylglycine levels decreased in plasma post-abx, in contrast to increased levels in fecal samples (Fig. 2D). Microbial substrates we identified in plasma generally had a smaller fold change relative to microbial products. Four of the five named substrates in plasma were medium-chain fatty acids or triglycerides (Fig. 4D).

We identified hundreds of EEN-derived plasma metabolites during microbiome depletion, including triacylglycerols or glycerophospholipids, whereas carnitines were markers of an omnivore diet (Fig. 4E). Caprylic, sebacic, and hexadecanedioic acids were associated with EEN only in the context of a depleted microbiome, whereas capric and phytanic acids were EEN-derived before and after microbiome depletion (Fig. 4F).

We identified 12 named metabolites and 75 unnamed metabolic features to be omnivore-derived in plasma during microbiome depletion. Masilinic acid, ectoine, trigonelline, and 1-methylhistidine were omnivore-derived in both fecal and plasma samples. Masilinic acid is prevalent in olive oil. Piperine is associated with black pepper. Only three of the named omnivore-derived metabolites, ectoine, hydroxyproline, and PC P36:4, were unique to the context of microbiome depletion (Fig. 4F); the remaining metabolites were associated with the omnivore diet before and after depletion.

Application of gut microbial metabolite atlas to inflammatory bowel disease

Finally, we sought to apply our atlas of microbial metabolites to a previously published study of inflammatory bowel disease (IBD) to illustrate how our results can be used to annotate metabolomics of complex gastrointestinal conditions. We investigated to what extent metabolites that are altered in gut dysbiosis were microbiome-derived. We integrated our atlas with fecal metabolomics data from the Human Microbiome Project (HMP) using Human Microbiome Database identifiers [21]. Of the 518 named metabolites in the HMP data set, 414 had corresponding IDs in our metabolite atlas, which included 58 microbial products and 64 substrates. A total of 40 diet-derived metabolites overlapped between the two data sets, 8 of which were also microbial products and 12 of which were substrates.

We compared metabolite levels between control, non-dysbiotic IBD, and dysbiotic IBD subjects. In dysbiotic IBD, 84 metabolites increased and 24 decreased relative to controls (Fig. 5A). A total of 28 microbial substrates were increased in dysbiosis, and none was decreased, whereas 10 microbial products were decreased in dysbiosis and 5 were increased. Together, these results suggest that the dysbiotic microbial community has a reduced ability to consume and produce metabolites.

Microbial substrates increased with dysbiosis, including conjugated primary bile acids and a variety of carnitines (Fig. 5B). Microbial products that decreased with dysbiosis included secondary bile acid lithocholic acid, and CAR C20:4. Only four microbial-derived metabolites increased in dysbiosis: 7-ketodeoxycholic, phenyllactic, p-hydroxyphenylacetic, and 2-aminobutyric acids. Only a few metabolites were different between the non-dysbiotic IBD group and controls: SM 18:1 and LPC 18:0, microbiome substrates; as well as phenyllactic acid and 4-hydroxystyrene, microbiome products. Thus, the metabolite atlas developed from controlled human experiments provided an additional layer of information to metabolites involved in IBD-induced dysbiosis.

Discussion

In this in vivo study, we identified microbial and diet metabolites within the context of human physiology and the healthy human gut microbiome. Using untargeted fecal and plasma metabolomics profiles of 20 human subjects, we identified microbial-derived metabolites by comparing metabolite levels before and after gut microbiome depletion and identified diet-derived metabolites by comparing subjects on omnivore and EEN diets when their gut microbiomes were depleted. Our atlas validates previous literature and provides new candidates for future studies.

Primary bile acids are produced in the liver and secreted into the gut lumen to emulsify fats and help with digestion [22]. The bile acids that are not reabsorbed into the bloodstream interact with the gut microbiome, where they are deconjugated using the bile salt hydrolase (BSH) gene and dehydroxylated using the bile acid inducible (bai) operon [1]. Bacteria regulate the levels of bile acids in the gut [23] due to the toxicity of bile acids, especially to Gram-positive bacteria [24]. In our dataset, we see a drastic decrease in unconjugated bile acids and an increase in conjugated bile acids with gut purge, which points to impeded BSH and bai transformations. Despite BSH being ubiquitous in the gut microbiome [25], the levels of unconjugated secondary bile acids remain low 7 days after the gut purge. The effects of reduced BSH activity can also be seen in plasma, since major unconjugated bile acids are almost nonexistent in the depleted microbiome, suggesting they are not deconjugated in the gut to be re-absorbed and re-circulated. Furthermore, the levels of conjugated primary bile acids are higher in dysbiotic IBD subjects, which points to impaired bacterial bile acid modification [21]. Furthermore, we identified two of the recently discovered bacterial bile acid amidates: tyrosocholic and leucocholic acids in the fecal samples [20, 26] as microbial metabolites with the functionality quickly reinstated during the recovery phase.

Along with bile acids, bilirubin is another metabolite secreted into the gut lumen. In the liver, heme is first converted into biliverdin and subsequently into bilirubin [27]. The BilR gene has recently been discovered to convert bilirubin to urobilinogen by certain Clostridium and Ruminococcus species [10]. In our dataset, the molecules that are produced by the host remain unchanged with gut purge; however, the microbial products mesobilirubinogen and l-urobilin are decreased.

Aromatic amino acids, tryptophan, phenylalanine, and tyrosine are precursors to various microbial metabolites. For example, Clostridium species containing the fld gene cluster reduce aromatic amino acid tryptophan to 3-indolepropionic acid, and phenylalanine to phenyllactic acid [2], which we correctly identify as microbial products in our analysis. We also identify phenylacetic acid, produced by oxidizing phenylalanine, as a microbial product and its host conjugated form phenylacetylglutamine as a microbial substrate [2]. Once phenylalanine is reduced by the microbiome, it enters the bloodstream to be modified by the host to produce benzoate [18]. Benzoate can also be synthesized by plants from phenylalanine [28] and ingested as part of the diet. Benzoate is conjugated by glycine in the liver to produce hippurate to decrease its fat solubility and for the body to get rid of extra glycine to regulate the levels of amino acids that are used as neurotransmitters [29]. Hippurate is a common urinary metabolite and has been identified as a marker for gut microbiome diversity [30]. Once in the gut, hippurate can be metabolized by the gut microbiome through both anaerobic and aerobic pathways, the latter of which produces pyrocatechol [31]. Another hippurate derivative gentisate was nearly undetectable in germ-free mice compared to conventional mice [32]. Furthermore, gentisate and hydrocinnamate, another phenylalanine derivative, are markers of irritable bowel syndrome, a condition that is often treated by reducing fermentable oligosaccharides, disaccharides, monosaccharides, and polyols (FODMAPs) in the diet [33]. Another source of benzoate is dietary polyphenols, which get converted into hydrocinnamic acid by the gut microbiome and transported to the liver to undergo beta-oxidation to produce benzoate [29]. We identified hydrocinnamic acid as a microbial product in the fecal samples. We identified a similar compound, cinnamoylglycine, as a microbial product in plasma. This suggests that polyphenol products are absorbed through the intestines to be conjugated by the host and circulated systemically. The presence of cinnamoylglycine in blood or urine may indicate non-dysbiotic microbiome since it is a biomarker for colonization resistance with Clostridioides difficile in mice [34]. Benzoate and its microbial derivatives gentisate, pyrocatechol, and cinnamoylglycine were only detected in the omnivore diet group, suggesting that diet is the main source of benzoate in this study.

Fatty acids are esterified to acyl-CoAs upon cellular absorption and converted into acylcarnitines to enable the transport of fatty acids into mitochondria for beta-oxidation. In our study, acylcarnitines with shorter acyl chains are identified as omnivore-derived; however, the majority of acylcarnitines are most likely secreted into the digestive tract as a component of bile [35]. Numerous acylcarnitines are elevated in the feces of patients with IBD, where they are positively correlated with the abundance of Enterobacteriaceae, a signature for “dysbiosis” [4, 21, 36]. Based on intestinal cell culture models, acylcarnitines can be absorbed either apically or basolaterally by the intestinal epithelium, where they can be used as an alternative energy source to the short-chain fatty acid butyrate [4]. However, based on the batch culture of human stool, palmitoyl carnitine (C16) can be consumed by the gut microbial community [4]. Carnitine, a quaternary amine, can be utilized by a variety of bacteria as a carbon and/or nitrogen source, osmoprotectant, or electron acceptor [37,38,39,40]. The results shown in Fig. 2G, where carnitine and a variety of acylcarnitines are elevated upon the depletion of the human gut microbiota, are consistent with previous literature that bacterial taxa in the gut microbiota are capable of consuming these molecules [38, 41]. The specific bacterial taxa responsible for this effect and the impact of either carnitine or acylcarnitines on the gut microbiome will require additional investigation.

The nutrition formula used for EEN in this study is a casein-based diet recommended as a first line of therapy for children with Crohn’s disease to induce remission. Uncertainty remains regarding the mechanisms behind the therapeutic effect; possibilities include reducing bowel movements, allowing it to rest, and a low FODMAP diet benefits hypersensitive patients as it lacks any dietary fiber, lactose, or gluten and is in liquid form [42]. In our study, we were able to identify EEN-derived fatty acids of various lengths, including medium-chain fatty acids (MCFAs), both in the gut and plasma. The EEN formula is enriched with MCFAs as they are more easily absorbed from the gut lumen directly through the portal circulation compared to their longer counterparts, which need to be transported as part of chylomicrons into the lymphatic system [43]. MCFAs are associated with regulating inflammation and the gut epithelial barrier [44]. Furthermore, compared to the omnivore diet, EEN contained higher levels of longer triacylglycerides both in fecal and plasma samples.

The subjects in the omnivore group only consumed food from two predefined menus engineered to match the macronutrients of the EEN formula [17]. This allowed us to identify omnivore-derived metabolites from a relatively small number of subjects. Omnivore-derived metabolites we identified were either plant or animal-based. Plants use the shikimate pathway to biosynthesize benzoic acids, which are then precursors to various essential metabolites including aromatic amino acids [45]. As EEN completely lacked plant material, shikimate was the metabolite with the greatest fold change between the two diet groups. Humans consume amino acids and their derivatives found in meat through the omnivore diet. In our dataset, even though histidine levels were comparable between the omnivore and EEN diets, histidine derivatives had higher levels in the omnivore diet, making them ideal biomarkers. Among these metabolites, methylhistidine is a marker for skeletal muscle breakdown [46], and anserine is the methylated form of alanine-histidine dipeptide found in cardiac and skeletal muscles [47]. Histamine is a signaling molecule of primordial origins, therefore found across various life forms that humans ingest. It is generally associated with allergic response and gastric acid secretion, though it is also released as a response to exercise and therefore found in the skeletal muscle [48]. The reason histidine derivatives in particular had higher fold changes between omnivore and EEN diets compared to other amino acid derivatives requires further investigation.

Despite dramatic changes in gut metabolites with gut purge, most metabolites recovered within four days after stopping antibiotics in the omnivore group, whereas recovery in the EEN group was delayed. This is consistent with the recovery of microbial density in the omnivore group within a short timeframe in our original analysis [17]. Although the microbiome composition remained perturbed from its pre-antibiotic configuration at the end of the study, a vast majority of microbial metabolites returned to their pre-antibiotic concentrations. This suggests that, although microbiome disruption can persist for substantial time frames following antibiotic exposure, the metabolic capacity of the gut microbial community may recover more quickly.

The metabolites in the gut either freely diffuse through the gut barrier or are actively transported by the host. The rest are excreted without being absorbed in the gut. Despite regulation in the bloodstream by homeostasis and normalization by the hepatic circulation, a small number of plasma metabolites were still altered by the intervention. Similarly, in a study comparing metabolomics profiles of germ-free and conventional mice, they identified 4 times more microbe-derived metabolites in the gut than in serum [16]. The metabolites we identified in plasma were mainly bile acids. About 95% of both conjugated and unconjugated bile acids are re-absorbed into the portal bloodstream to be taken up by hepatocytes [22]. We also identified two metabolites produced from amino acids by bacteria: 3-indolepropionic acid, produced by reducing tryptophan [2], and phenylacetylglutamine, produced by oxidizing phenylalanine by bacteria and then getting conjugated with glycine by the host in the liver [2]. The latter has previously been identified in plasma to enhance platelet adhesion via binding to host adrenergic receptors, resulting in increased cardiovascular disease risk [49].

Inflammatory bowel disease is a chronic inflammation of the gastrointestinal tract. Along with genetic disposition, environmental factors such as the gut microbiome are key components of the complex disease [50,51,52]. During active inflammation, a bacterial and metabolomic perturbation is observed in a state called dysbiosis [4, 21, 36]. In this study, by annotating the metabolites altered in dysbiosis with our atlas of microbial and diet metabolites, we confirm that most of the metabolites increasing in dysbiosis are gut microbial substrates and decreasing in dysbiosis are gut microbial products. Furthermore, microbial metabolites did not rise and fall to the same degree in dysbiosis compared to our intervention, so this type of analysis allows us to observe which components of microbial metabolism are the first to disappear or diminish in perturbed or reduced-diversity communities. For example, microbial products with the highest effect sizes in our atlas, lithocholic acid and hydrocinnamic acid, were lower in dysbiosis; however, butyric acid or gentisic acid were not altered in the HMP2 dataset. Similarly, acylcarnitines we identified as substrates in our dataset were also altered in dysbiosis, but hippuric acid was not. This study can further be used to annotate metabolite shifts in other dysbiotic conditions such as recurrent Clostridioides difficile infections [53].

We studied metabolomics profiles of 20 subjects on either an EEN or an omnivore diet. Even with a small number of subjects, we were able to reduce the noise in the data by carefully designing and controlling both diets. However, a known microbial substrate, bilirubin levels, did not increase post-abx. There may be molecules with smaller effect sizes that we were not able to detect due to issues of statistical power. The omnivore-derived metabolites are strictly associated with the contents of the two pre-defined menus and are not representative across all food items. The intervention was a combination of an antibiotic cocktail and gut purge to decrease the microbial biomass. Even though this was effective in identifying microbial products and substrates, it is not possible to disentangle the effects of either intervention or gauge potential changes in host gastrointestinal secretions as a response to the intervention. It is also possible that the levels of some metabolites increased after the purge solely because the faster transit time did not allow the metabolites to be absorbed from the intestines by the host. For example, amino acids that increased post-abx could be explained by both inefficient absorption and reduced bacterial metabolism. Furthermore, the majority of the microbe- and diet-derived metabolites we identified were unnamed metabolic features, highlighting the vast metabolic potential of the microbiome that is yet unexplored. As new information on the metabolite spectrum becomes available, we can further annotate the metabolites that we have identified in this study. Finally, exploring urine metabolites would have been valuable to establish the microbial metabolites that are excreted.

In this study, we identified gut microbial products and substrates as well as diet-derived molecules using a controlled diet study in humans. Although many metabolites were consistent with previous literature, we identified new metabolites that add to our current understanding of gut microbiome metabolism. Our comprehensive atlas of human gut microbiome metabolites can be applied across a wide range of future studies to better interpret the metabolic consequences of gut microbiome perturbations.

Methods

Study cohort

As previously described in the FARMM study [17], 20 subjects between the ages of 18 and 60 who were on an omnivore diet were enrolled. The subjects resided in an inpatient research unit throughout the duration of the study. Half were randomly assigned to receive an EEN diet, and the other half were given a pre-defined omnivore diet during the study. Two omnivore diet menus were designed to have a similar macronutrient composition to the EEN formula. The subjects in the omnivore group alternated between the two menus, though all subjects were assigned the same menu on a given day. On days 6, 7, and 8, subjects received a combination of 500 mg vancomycin and 1000 mg neomycin orally every 6 h. On day 7, participants consumed a liquid diet consisting of their choice of apple juice, cranberry juice, clear broth, jello, tea, or ginger ale and 4L of polyethylene glycol-based bowel purgative (GoLytely®) to purge their gut. The subjects were back on their respective diets on day 8 before sample collection on day 9. The study was concluded on day 15.

Metabolomics data

Blood and fecal samples were collected on days 1, 5, 9, 12, and 15 of the study. As described in the original FARMM study [17], stool samples were homogenized using a bead mill (TissueLyser II, QIAGEN), and the aqueous homogenates were aliquoted for metabolite profiling analyses. Four separate LC–tandem MS methods were used to measure polar metabolites and lipids in each sample. Methods 1, 2, and 3 were conducted using two LC–MS systems composed of Nexera X2 UHPLC systems (Shimadzu Scientific Instruments) and Q Exactive Hybrid Quadrupole-Orbitrap MSs (Thermo Fisher Scientific), and method 4 was conducted using a Nexera X2 UHPLC (Shimadzu Scientific Instruments) coupled to an Exactive Plus Orbitrap MS (Thermo Fisher Scientific). Raw data were processed using Progenesis QI software (NonLinear Dynamics) for feature alignment, nontargeted signal detection, and signal integration. Targeted processing of a subset of known metabolites was conducted using TraceFinder 3.3 software (Thermo Fisher Scientific). The raw output obtained for the original study was processed further. The redundant features were removed via clustering. Filtering was applied to lower abundance peaks that eluted within a 0.026 min RT window and had a Spearman coefficient of greater than 0.9. The metabolites were re-annotated based on newer spectra databases and nomenclature since the publication of the original study.

Statistical analysis

The metabolites obtained from both fecal and plasma samples were analyzed in R software language and visualized using the ggplot2 package [54]. The area under the curve (AUC) values were log10-transformed for analysis. To detect microbe-derived metabolites, metabolite levels at day 5 (pre-abx) were subtracted from study day 9 (post-abx) within subject and tested if they were different than 0 using linear models. This test was done for subjects in the EEN and omnivore groups separately. The same strategy was used to test for the recovery of the metabolites using samples from days 12 and 15. To find metabolites that are different between diets, linear models were used to differentiate metabolites between omnivore and EEN diet groups for pre-abx and post-abx separately. For each comparison, tests were adjusted for false discovery rate using the Benjamini–Hochberg method.

Human Microbiome Project data analysis

The metabolomics and metagenomics data from the HMP2 project were obtained from the website per the data availability statement [21]. The dysbiosis activity scores were calculated using the R script provided in the manuscript, and the same cutoff was used to define dysbiosis and non-dysbiosis IBD subjects. The metabolites were matched to the FARMM metabolite data by HMDB IDs. Linear mixed effects models were used to find the metabolites with altered levels in non-dysbiotic and dysbiotic IBD compared to controls using study groups as fixed effects and subject IDs as random effects. For each term in the linear model, tests were adjusted for false discovery rate using the Benjamini–Hochberg method. The metabolites that were altered in either non-dysbiotic or dysbiotic IBD were then annotated with the microbe- and diet-derived metabolites identified in this paper.

Data availability

Metabolomics data are available at the National Metabolomics Data Repository ( [www.metabolomicsworkbench.org] (http:/www.metabolomicsworkbench.org) ) under accession number PR001024. Metabolite annotations and levels are available under https://doi.org/10.5281/zenodo.16651867. The code generated during this study are available at Github at https://github.com/ctanes/atlas_of_microbial_metabolites.git.
